let's talk about blazer uh if you don't uh know what blazer is it's a single page app framework for building client-side web
applications but using c-sharp uh it was originally this guy steve sanderson's pet project
and he demoed it at a conference and a few microsoft people saw it wow we want this it's absolutely fantastic
and what they liked about it is that you can code your client-side stuff from c-sharp
instead of javascript which if you've got a bunch of c sharp devs then you can
just reuse that knowledge base then to create web apps which is great you know or reduce the team even potentially
um it's very much like asp.net so it's razer sort of syntax and html and there's two
different varieties two different flavors if you like um there's server side blazer and as the
name suggests that actually runs on the server and there's a little thin client that runs on the browser and the server side
just passes changes to the page dom changes down to the page when they need to happen
and the page updates it uh what's good about that is that if you don't want to have to put your uh software onto a client's machine
then it you put it on this server side and it keeps it all locked away which is great the downside is if you lose network
connection the web web page stops working and and you can't use it so there is
something called client-side web assembly and this is really i think where microsoft are putting uh all the regs
and that essentially lets you run a net virtual machine in the browser and it passes down actual
proper net standard dlls down to your application that's running in the browser so this is a proper.net
application running in the browser and it's super fast as well and there's speed improvements coming for that all
the time so this is what i'm going to be using is the client side and in actual fact i'm going to use
something called hosted client-side webassembly where i've got a server part and a
